p.s: Angie Thomas presents Starr's state of mind by using a certain point of view and different narrative techniques.
The excerpt's perspective is a first person protagonist.
By using this point of view we, the readers can identify ourselfsourselves in Starr.
We also see through her eyes and experience and relive the actions in her perspective.
The reader only knows Starr's thoughts, it is a limited point of view.
By that the reader can understand Starr's decisions and feelings.
This shows by the use of first person pronouns, such as I and We in line one, five, 13...
The scene begins by presenting place and situation in a panoramic mode.
The author just lists the things Starr is seeing.
When Starr recognizes the place a flashback starts (l. 5- l. 9 and l. 19- l. 22).
The reader sees through Starr's eyes and is reliving the situation, when Khalil was shot to deaddeath.
In the flashbacks a past action is written in present and here partly cursive.
By the time Ms. Ofrah spots Starr in the crowd anand heads towards her, the narrative technique switches to a scenic mode (l. 25).
Ms. Ofrah and Starr are having a conversation and Starr tells her attorney, why she is out and protesting.

In Starr's opinion talking, doing and interview and going to the court, didn't change the court's decision on not penalizing the police officer, that killed Khalil, that is why she wanted to go protest.
This part is written in a dialogue between Starr and Ms. Ofrah, it is portrayed with direct speech, wichwhich contributes to the reader identifying with Starr.
The scene continues in a scenic mode, when Starr is given the bullhorn and she is speaking to the crowd.
In the following part it seems like Starr is nervous (l. 41-49).
This is because Starr's thought in this moment are all written down, this moment is presented detailed.
It feels like we are in the situation of Starr, e.g. Shit, I have no idea what to say.
This writing style evokes the same thoughts on being in Starr's position, being her.
After Starr is encouraged by the crowd, she is no longer nervous, e.g. You know what, fuck it.
Starr speaking to the activists and protesters is also written as direct speech, with the use of quotation marks, interuptedinterrupted by Starr's thoughts.
She says that Khalil's deaddeath is unjustified, that the police officers are biased and that we'll keep protesting.
Written as direct speech and as a first person protagonist the reader has the same opinion as Starr and wants to support her.
Overall the use of narrative techniques and the point of view in this chapter are used to making Starr's position and feelings clear.
The reader should understand and aggreeagree to Starr's actions after the decision of the court has been announced.
